importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in 2007, establishing himself as one of the country’s most promising young talents.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Naroditsky's rise from early youth championships in 2007 to graduation from Stanford in 2019 illustrates his long-standing and impactful career in chess, education, and public engagement.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before his senior year in high school and won multiple national championships early in life.
Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, a milestone that established his international reputation.
He graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
He authored a chess manual at age 14 and became a regular contributor to Chess Life and a New York Times chess columnist in 2022.
He built massive online followings on YouTube (nearly 500,000 subscribers) and Twitch (340,000 followers), where he livestreamed games and made complex chess accessible to casual viewers.
The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his death, recognizing him as a talented player, commentator, and educator.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor, showing his widespread impact on the chess world.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as a head coach, confirmed his death and described him as a cherished member of the chess community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at 29, leaving behind a legacy as a world-class player, educator, and digital chess influencer. Born in the San Francisco Bay Area, he won major youth championships including the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007 and earned grandmaster status before high school. He pursued a degree in history at Stanford University, graduating in 2019. Naroditsky became a prominent public figure through his accessible teaching and livestreamed gameplay on YouTube and Twitch, where he amassed nearly half a million subscribers and 340,000 followers. Recognized by the International Chess Federation and the Saint Louis Chess Club, he was praised as a passionate educator and community pillar. His death prompted a moment of silence during the 2025 US Chess Championship, and the Charlotte Chess Center confirmed his passing, emphasizing his role as a beloved mentor and friend to many in the chess world.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
